title: LiPo stick-pack case for old Tamiya chassis

description.text:
This case has the exact dimensions of the NiMH 6-cell stick packs and therefore fits perfectly old Tamiya chassis like M01..M04, TA01, TA02, TA03, TA05, DF01 (Hummer) and so on.

Video available at https://youtu.be/fDcPimm8l_0

The battery is a Zippy Compact 2S 2200mAh 35C LiPo battery.

There are plenty of "round" hardcase LiPo on the market, but the ones I found either do not fit at all (Turnigy 4200; fits only newer chassis like M05 and TT01) or are too long (LRP 3300, 4600) so you can't secure the battery. This case solves the issue, with battery capacity being the trade-off.

OpenSCAD source file included.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Ensure that your battery fits the dimensions in the OpenSCAD source file. Batteries are hand-made and have therefore some tolerance to them. Adjust if necessary.

We printed the case with supports so that the two mating surfaces are perfectly flat as they are touching the build plate. You could flip the STL around if you want to print without supports.

Print resolution does not matter, we printed at a fast 0.3 mm setting for a total print time of < 3 hours.

author: jackbond007

description.text: Just an idea, a crosshatch printed very thin (0.060mm on Ultimaker2+), then crumpled up into a ball to form a light meta-material structure.

comments.text:
I did some work in metamaterials for a while. And I can give you some pointers if you want to experiment:
1) Metamaterials work based on conduction and absorption of waves, so the structures that "conduct" cant touch the other structures that conduct. This is why a ball is probably a bad idea, although slightly shifted sheets might do it.
2) Metamaterials theoretically work at ALL wavelengths, with the repetition length being closely related to the wavelength (around a factor of 2) of the wave you want to interact with. Bad news: you will never be able to make an OPTICAL metamaterial (invisibility cloak) with a 3D printer, because visible light is around 500 NANOmeters, the smallest features you do on a FFF printer are 50 MICROmeters (or 100x bigger).
3) Based on the size you can make with a 3D printer, you are either going to be experimenting with sound, or microwaves, if microwaves, I suggest using a metallic spray paint to make the conductive structures, and normal filament, or saran wrap to make the insulating structures. If you are using sound, you need to know what the speed of sound in filament AT THE WAVELENGTH of your repetition length. I think you are then going to work in "slowness" (1/velocity), if you want to use the equations from optics.
4) Synonyms: negative-index material, NIM, fishnet structure, (metamaterials are closely related to) photonic crystals.
5) Search strategy: http://patft.uspto.gov/netahtml/PTO/search-adv.htm, https://www.google.com/patents, https://sci-hub.io/, look at the patent 8345349, and the references it cites.

author: SamGraham

description.text:
I had to get a new key for a rusty old drill chuck, however the one I got from the shop did not fit, as the peg diameter was slightly too large. I figured that I could just grind the peg to size with a rasp/file by turning the key in another drill, but I could not fit the key in the drill chuck due to the key handles being crimped in place. I decided to make a fitting to mount the key in a drill. Slide one half onto each handle of the key and use a zip tie to hold in place, then insert into the drill chuck.

I have no idea if anyone else might find this useful, but I just wanted to illustrate an idea I was able to quickly implement and solve a problem I had. I guess this could be a starting point for a drill lathe or wire twister? Also as a bonus this "chuck" could also be used to "drive" the key in another drill chuck when you're too lazy to turn it yourself ? :P

I designed this model in Wings3d and printed the file in PLA using low quality settings with support. The finish is rough but the part was effective.

EDIT: Just a few quick thoughts on safety: obviously drill chucks & keys were never meant to be used like this -
If you ever have any reason to spin up a drill with parts like this on the end, BE CAREFUL! Wear eye protection and watch out for the spinning key handles. I didn't have any issues with my part, but if the part is broken or poorly mounted in the drill, of course there is a hazard of parts being thrown from the end of the drill!

We recently added insulating styrofoam panels to our tilting garage door.
After trying tapes and other things, I still had no way to hold in the side which isn't wedged under the frame of the door panels.

The clips do this job. I used two per panel.

I had some problems with the z-runner cracking at the hinge, and when I attempted to print a replacement I had repeated problems with the hinge gap filling in, so I remixed it to a two-part solution with a reinforced hinge.

Requires an extra M3x15mm bolt, M3 nut and a couple M3 washers in addition to the hardware of the original part. Also I needed a larger diameter bearing, though I had the same problem with the original part, so it may or may not apply to your machine.

Remixed from the original z-runner part by RepRapPro:

title: Testors Paint Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Designed to be fast to print and use a small amount of material, this holds a typical set (9 bottles) of Testors model paint. The height goes almost up to the neck of the bottle.

Added a second version that has thicker outer edges so that it is more sturdy. There's nothing wrong with the first one, it's just thinner to save filament if one wants to, but it's also obviously weaker so might not hold up to long term punishment. For something that isn't moved around much or at all and is sitting on a shelf or table, the first one is the most efficient option, and prints quickly. I just thought I'd give a sturdier option for those who may want or need it.

description.text:
This is an enclose for an IKEA Tradfri switch. IKEA launched a series of IoT products, the switch can be hacked and connected to eg a Wemos Mini programmed to issue MQTT commands.

Search youtube for

IKEA Tradfri IOT Smart Lighting System Hack
by Andreas Spiess (video 140)

for more details.

Removing the switch from its original enclosure can be destructive, so a new enclosure is needed. I modified a small bowl (shaving), and added a slot and groove to allow a usb lead to be inserted into the base.

The fit on my printer is a snug interference fit, and no glue was needed to hold the switch in place, and there's a series of small internal indentations (from original shaving lid use) where the original switch clips can just fit in.

title: Dielectric Test Cavity for 3D Printing Filament

description.text:
I created a resonant cavity used to test the dielectric constant and loss tangent of filament used for 3D printing. We are 3D printing microwave lenses, and need to know these properties. This is a WR-90 TE101 cavity with a hole in the center where filament can be inserted. Perturbation theory tells you how the resonant frequency and Q will change when dielectric is added to the cavity.

The formulae can be found on Wikipedia

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cavity_perturbation_theory

Experimental Results

Empty cavity

fc = 8.139134 GHz
3 dB 8.138991
3 dB 8.139271
Qc = 29016.52
S11 = -25.336 dB

ABS Black from Stratasys Fortus

fs = 8.048269 GHz
3 dB 8.047937
3 dB 8.048622
Qs = 11757.88
S11 = -19.974 dB

Calculated from Perturbation Theory

er' = 2.609524
er'' = 0.003606

Commercial vendor specifies er' = 2.7 - 2.9, er'' = 0.0032-0.0035

Premix 20280 Custom Filament

fs = 7.928404 GHz
3 dB 7.927239
3 dB 7.929605
Qs = 3350.974
S11 = -11.327 dB

Calculated from Perturbation Theory

er' = 4.789159
er'' = 0.018815

Commercial vendor specifies er' = 4.4, er'' = 0.004

Commercial dielectric test equipment is very expensive ($20k). Feel free to download and 3D print these STL files.

At this frequency, FDM printing might be OK, but STL printing is better. I used commercial SLA 3D printing. I had my parts copper electroplated, but hand painting with silver paint would be OK for this device.

The WR-90 Cavity dimensions are 0.9 in x 0.4 in x 30 mm. The hole in the cavity is at the center of the broad wall, corresponding to the electric field maximum. This is also a minimum wall current point, so the hole minimally perturbs the cavity. The hole diameter is 1.75 mm, matching standard 3D printing filament.

The round aperture goes between a commercial WR-90 coax. to waveguide launcher and the cavity. This aperture provides near critical coupling with a diameter of 4.25 mm for the empty cavity (no filament present). This was tested using HFSS and optimized empirically.

The dielectric constant for regular ABS is too low for our purpose. We ordered specially formulated filament from Premix which has a published dielectric constant of 4.4.

print_settings.Notes:: This is a fairly easy print. Just set the puzzle on the build plate so that the big face is facing downwards and start printing. Due to the fact that this is a print-in-place-Design, you don't need to assemble it or print multiple pieces. The puzzle should be functional right of the printer.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is another trivial puzzle I've created. The tangram block is a puzzle with 4 pieces that can rotate around a center. What makes it special, is that it can block certain moves due to the overhang of bigger pieces. Thus, it sometimes isn't solvable in only 4 moves like expected on the first glance. It is more a collectors item than a real puzzle as it is really easy to solve. However, it is fun to play around with it. It reminds me of the Rubik's snake and can definitely be given to smaller children as "First twisty puzzle". For everybody else, it is just a fast and easy print to add to a collection.

Please note that this is a print-in-place design. That makes it very easy to print but also a bit loose compared to assembly-puzzles.

I hope you have fun with my creation and would be happy if anybody tried it and added it to the "Made"-section.

Check out the video of this puzzle now: https://youtu.be/0AMlB2NivPA

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

This is a fairly easy print. Just set the puzzle on the build plate so that the big face is facing downwards and start printing. Due to the fact that this is a print-in-place-Design, you don't need to assemble it or print multiple pieces. The puzzle should be functional right of the printer.

Post-Processing?

No post-processing is neccessary. However, if you are planning to add stickers like I did, i'd recommend to sand the outer faces so that the stickers have a smoother surface to stick to.

But I wanted to change some things, so I decided to build my own tank. This tank is not compatible with the above speed tank. It has been completely redesigned.

ich habe bei Thingiverse diesen Speed Tank (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2024364) gesehen und war von dem Konzept begeistert.
Ich wollte aber einige Dinge ändern und so entschied ich mich, einen eigenen Tank zu bauen. Dieser Tank ist mit dem oben genannten Speed Tank nicht kompatibel, da er von Grund auf neu konstruiert wurde.

Ich möchte die Beschreibung gerne auf Deutsch und Englisch erstellen.
Leider ist mein Englisch alles andere als perfekt. Sollten im Text Fehler sein würde ich mich um eine kleine Nachricht freuen.

General information

Printing time: approx. 100 hours
Needed filament: about 1.5kg
Printing board: at least 200mm x 200mm
Costs: approx. 150 Euro incl. filament, excl. receiver, remote control and battery. See below for an overview of costs.

Allgemeine Informationen

Druckzeit: ca. 100 Stunden
Benötigtes Filament: ca. 1,5kg
Druckbrett: mindestens 200mm x 200mm
Kosten: ca. 150 Euro inkl. Filament, exkl. Empfänger, Fernsteuerung und Akku. Eine Preisübersicht findet ihr weiter unten.


Print setting

I printed all parts with the following settings.
Material: PLA / PETG
Diameter of the nozzle: 0.4 mm
Layer height: 0.2 mm
Printing speed: 60-80mm / s
Contour: 3
Top layers: 3
Bottom layers: 3
Infill: 30%
Support: no

Druckeinstellung

Alle Teile wurden mit folgenden Druckeinstellungen gedruckt
Material: PLA / PETG
Düsendurchmesser: 0,4mm
Schichthöhe: 0.2mm
Druckgeschwindigkeit: 60-80mm/s
Kontur: 3
Geschlossene Deckschichten: 3
Geschlossene Bodenschichten: 3
Infill: 30 %
Support: nein


Print overview

Following parts must print multiple times:

2 x drive_gear_brushless_14_V1
2 x gear_36_18_V1
2 x track_drive_wheel_54_V1
8 x track_wheel_V1
2 x track_wheel_tension_V1
96 x track_V1
2 x logo_V1

In this list everything is summarize. You can also find information about material, printing time and print quantity.

Zu den gedruckten Teilen wird folgendes Zubehör benötigt:

In folgender Liste ist alles nochmal zusammengefasst. Zudem findet ihr auch Informationen zum Preis.

click to zoom image


Screw list

In this list you find information which part need which screws and nuts.

Schraubentabelle

Folgend eine Übersicht, aus der ersichtlich ist, welche Schrauben für welche gedruckten Teile benötigt werden. Eine bessere Beschreibung inkl. Bilder folgt in den nächsten Tagen.

click to zoom image


Different types of motors

At the moment you can use 3 different types of motors:

1) (tested) Sunnysky X2212 980KV Brushless Motor (printed gear)

2) (not tested) Brushless Motor with 3,175mm shaft and a max diameter of 28,5mm (960-1000KV)
You need a metal gear module 1 with 14 teeth. (Like this one https://www.voelkner.de/products/115422/Stahl-Zahnrad-14-Z-Modul-1-B3-2.html)

3) (not tested) Brushed or Brushless 540 Motor.
You need a metal gear module 1 with 10-14 teeth. (Like this one https://www.voelkner.de/products/115406/Stahl-Zahnrad-12-Z-Modul-1-B3-2.html)

When you will use the 3rd version you needn´t following things:
-left_motor_bracket_brushless_V1_1
-left_gearbox_1
-left_gearbox_2
-right_motor_bracket_brushless
-right_gearbox_1
-right_gearbox_2
-drive_gear_brushless_14

But you need 2 x 540_motor_bracket_V1.

Verschiedene Motortypen

Momentan kann man 3 verschiedene Motortypen verwenden:

1) (getestet) Sunnysky X2212 980KV Brushless Motor (gedrucktes Zahnrad)

2) (nicht getestet) Brushless Motor mit einem 3,175mm Schaft und einem maximalen Durchmesser von 28.5mm (960-1000KV).
Dazu brauch man ein Modul 1 Metal Zahnrad mit 14 Zähnen.
(https://www.voelkner.de/products/115422/Stahl-Zahnrad-14-Z-Modul-1-B3-2.html)

3) (nicht getestet) Brushed or Brushless 540 Motor.
Dazu brauch man ein Modul 1 Metal Zahnrad mit 10-14 Zähnen.(https://www.voelkner.de/products/115406/Stahl-Zahnrad-12-Z-Modul-1-B3-2.html)

Wenn du die 3te Version verwendest brauchst du folgende Teile nicht drucken:

-left_gearbox_1
-left_gearbox_2
-right_motor_bracket_brushless
-right_gearbox_1

comments.author: Oger

comments.text:
Yes, 2 of these ESC should work. You can just hook the power input cables from both ESCs in parallel, there is no need for 2 batteries I would say. For my old dual brushless setup, I simply soldered all 4 (2x + 2x -) ESC supply cables onto on XT60 connector.
The motors you choose draw 1,38 A at best efficiency, so I guess one should not draw more than 10 A even when it is not run at the most efficient torque and RPM. Do you have a multimeter or something similar to measure the current of a motor under load?
comments.author: ir_fuel

comments.text: Yeah I have a multimeter. So I would just snap off the connectors of the ESCs and solder them together to one connector then. Should be doable.
comments.author: Oger

comments.text:
I forgot to mention that you have to disconnect the red (+) line on the receiver cable of one of the ESCs. Because both ESC have a build in BEC to supply power to the receiver and servos if you have any. If you have both BEC outputs connected, you basically have the outputs of both BEC voltage regulators in parallel, which might damage the circuits.
So one ESC has all the cables connected (+ / - / signal), the other ESC only gets two cables (- / signal) connected to the receiver.
comments.author: ir_fuel

comments.text: Good to know. I saw the receiver has a separate power input, so I won't need to connect anything to that?
comments.author: Oger

comments.text:
No, you don't need the separate power input when using an ESC with BEC. On the receiver all - pins and all + pins are in parallel. So when you connect a single ESC with BEC, the receiver and servos have - and +5V (or +6V depending on the BEC) to work properly.
The separate power input is needed for setups where you connect only servos to the receiver. For example in a nitro car. You have one servo for throttle and one for steering, but there is no ESC which could power the receiver, so you plug a small battery-pack into the power input of the receiver.

comments.text: Just a remark from my side, as I wanted to use this tank as a robot platform myself. You might find the driving and accelerating characteristics of the tank somewhat problematic, when it comes to slow and precise driving. With the brushless motors, the tank has very little power when starting. So you can't climb over obstacles without giving a fair amount of throttle. The tank becomes powerful and goes uphill very well, but only at a higher speed. Crawling uphill or pulling itself over/on top of some obstacle does not work at low speed. Starting the tank when it is already standing on a slope or with some obstacle directly against the front track does not work at all. The motors just vibrate and buzz about in place, but they cannot turn. Its basically a race car.

comments.author: akabkn

comments.text:
That's exactly what I did in the first place, however, I did it with both motors and ESCs attached to channel 1 and 2. then, on the transmitter, I configured throttle to send on channel 1 and 2 at the same time.
I tried to do it exactly as you have written, same problem again: there are too many sound comming from the motor, but non of them is as you have written.
could it be that my frsky x4r-sb is giving the wrong protocol to the ESCs (PPM, PWM, CPPM,...)?
comments.author: Oger

comments.text: Hmmm, that's strange. Do you have a normal standard servo at hand? If the servo goes from -90° to 90° when attached to your throttle channel, I would think that the signal from your receiver is alright.
comments.author: akabkn

comments.text: more analysis has shown that the receiver indeed produces PWM signals. I can confirm that channel 1 produces a PWM signal from -124% (999us) -> 118% (2016us) (tested with ISDT BG-8S).
comments.author: Oger

comments.text: Nice data gathering! Good to know your receiver signal is, what it is supposed to be. So you were able to calibrate ESC 1 correctly and now it functions properly? Were you able to calibrate ESC 2 as well?
comments.author: akabkn

comments.text:
I had a much milder version of the same problem, one ESC would begin turning at a slightly higher throttle than the other once I had my mixes programmed for tank steering. I compensated by dding a small amount of offset in the first mix, like 9% or something like that. That took care of it.
Also, if your ESCs support bidirectional mode, you could use a v-tail mixer (a hardware mixer, very easy to use, just plug in!) and a pistol-type car transmitter, which personally I would find much more accurate to drive with. Might be a blessing in disguise ;-)
My ESCs I am pretty certain don't support bidirectional. They are 2 spares I had left over from an F550 drone build.
comments.author: Oger

comments.text:
Wanted to post my appreciation for this design. I've just finished assembling mine last night. I used most of the available remix mod parts, i've got the super bright bike light on the front, the grippier tracks, and the wheels with spiffy colored inserts. Color scheme is purple, grey, and black. Motor brackets are red just because that was the color of PETG I had on hand.
Only gotten to give it a quick test drive in my living room, but it looks like it will be an exciting and fun vehicle. I like the use of the outrunner type motors and standard air ESCs. The printed gearboxes, track geometry, chassis assembly, In general the whole design shows thoughtful and precise engineering with attention to the strengths and limitations of 3d printed parts. Hope to take some pictures soon and can then post a "make" with more description.
SO yeh, thanks for the design, and especially for sharing it!

comments.text: I am using the 20amp ESC and SS 980kv from the description list, they run really good once the tank has some speed. It is just that the start up is now working properly if it has some resistance (Like a hill or some angle)
comments.author: Oger

comments.text:
OK, so you are using the same components as I'm doing. My ESC is the 30 A version, but I measured the current draw and it is about 7,5 A @2S full throttle on grass.
I just did a few more tests and I think I know what you mean. The tank indeed needs some distance to build up speed until he is strong enough to go over edges or pull himself up a hill or angle.
I placed the front of the tracks directly against a ledge (book) about 40 mm hight and expected the tank to climb onto it on start up. Instead the motors just stuttered in place and whined.
The problem is the speed/torque behaviour of these kind of motor. At low speed i.e. starting, they have very little torque and they become more powerful as the speed goes up. At 30% throttle the tank easily goes up that book.
I guess that's the trade off for having a high top speed. A motor with a lower kV rating and the same power will be slower but stronger. I am actually thinking of using 600 kV motors, to have more ability to climb at lower speed.
Perhaps André could comment on how his tank is handling the start with some resistance going up hill.
comments.author: Trid3nt

comments.text: You should assume the electronics can get a little wet, but motor/esc's for cars tend be "waterproof" by default, or at least splash water proof. With some plastidip, its easy to make them fully submersible. Your receiver and FPV gear,  the protective case is probably enough, but these can also be completely waterproofed if you intend to drive in rain or through water. Look on youtube for tutorials, pretty easy with epoxy and/or some balloons. I actually considered making mine fully submersible and drive under water, but it turns out radio signals dont travel through water, so.. not much point :).

comments.author: P4man

comments.text: Let us know how the mixer works. Its possible it will reduce your throttle range, and the only way to get "full throttle" (and to just one motor) is giving, well full throttle + full steering. Full throttle + neutral steering may result in just 50% throttle. On most radio mixers you can define that, but Im not sure how the vtail mixer handles it. If its a problem, you could try recalibrating the ESCs to accept the ~50%  throttle signall as full throttle (and hope it doesnt shut down when it gets a signal >100%)
comments.author: chickey

comments.text:
I think the ESCs André used might actually have reverse.
I bought two "Emax Simon Series 30A" and in the manual there is an option D8 "Rotation Direction" where you can choose from Normal, Reverse and Bidirectional. Bidirectional is for 3D flying of multicopters, where you need to reverse the rotation to fly upside down. So stick in the middle is zero, stick up is clockwise and stick down is counter-clockwise.
I have not tested my ESCs yet, as I am waiting for the motors.
comments.author: Fribbler

comments.text:

I agree with you, we need a reverse on this tank. ;-) So, I have to reprogram, I'm going to figure out how.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7CUNx4kPw6w For more pictures and info:
http://jjshortcut.wordpress.com/2010/04/19/my-mini-servo-grippers-and-completed-robotic-arm/

To assemble the gripper you use m3 nuts and bolts. For the gripper parts you use nylock nuts so the gripper wont come loose. For more grip use some kind of soft foam which you glue on the grip parts with super glue. For connecting the horn of the servo to the right gear part use some small screws, like 2mm.

title: Lil' Tugger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Lil' Tugger is a cable strain relief gadget that has a number of uses but the main one is in protecting sockets from being damaged when a cable is accidentally ripped out.

Note: I've improved my design and added it to a new thing here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2452675

Twice now I’ve had my camera monitor fall off the hot shoe adapter. Once was after a bit of camera movement but the second was when I accidentally hooked the HDMI cable and yanked it off. I’m not too concerned about the monitor but both times it ripped out the micro HDMI plug on my Sony with some considerable force. Fortunately the HDMI socket on my camera handled the extreme handling without causing any permanent damage.

I tried Jerkstoppers but they were a pain to use... that's when I decided to build a better cable strain relief and I came up with my design called Lil’ Tuggers.

I've put together a short youtube video showcasing them here:-
https://youtu.be/sWLgZHM7_Ro

The Lil' Tugger is for protecting sockets by attaching to cables sized around hdmi or USB cables. There are two other sizes that can also be found here:-

Regular Tugger can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415093

Big Tugger can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415089

If my video or 3D models didn't answer all your questions then please ask below?

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sWLgZHM7_Ro" ></iframe>

description.text:
Une petite poulie pour éliminer les micro-rebonds de la courroie de X sur la petite Dagoma.
Elle vient en remplacement des roulements sur la partie droite du chariot X et permet d’améliorer, encore, la qualité d’impression.
J’ai renforcé l’axe par une entretoise inox de 10mm diam extérieur 4mm et intérieur 3mm, cela se trouve dans n’importe quelle grande surface de bricolage au milieu des rondelles et de visserie. J’ai pu tester la résistance de ces pièces dans le rotor de mon hélico et même en voltige, R.A.S. Donc sur la longévité, je n’ai pas de doute. Cela s’utilise sans graisses donc propre…
Je vous ai mis le gcode d’impression pour ceux qui n’aurai pas ou ne maîtriserai pas cura 2.5 car l’impression est en 0.06 de résolution (si si…. Elle y va la petite dago !) en en trame concentrique 100% de remplissage pour assurer la solidité et la propreté des dents (car cela reste petit, une GT2!) et j’ai utilisé un fil « chromatik » et une colle cyano pour fixer les trois parties de la poulie.
Je reste a dispo pour toutes questions ou modif…

title: Eachine Racer 250 FPV Top Camera Mount

description.text:
My drone flying skills are progressing in that my average speed is now faster; however, the default FPV camera isn't angled enough and thus I am now, more often than not, staring at the ground. In addition, I wasn't ready to add the fully flexible servo controlled FPV camera assembly. Thus, my weekend fix was to make a new FPV camera mount to replace the standard/provided mount.

While it is revision 3, I believe that the thickness can still be increased to add more camera angle; however, as other have pointed out, there is a 2-pin connector than eventually will be in the way as the angle is increased which will require, most likely, combined modification of the bottom plate and the top plate.

Regardless, I believe it is "done" in that I will be flying with this component "as is" for atleast this week.

title: Sony NEX-5 mount for 3DR Solo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount for Sony NEX-5 to use for 3DR solo. It allows you to use your camera in normal position and avoid flipped image.
It requires one of the GoPro compatible extenders to gain the full 90 degrees movement. I recommend using some sort of safety cable to attach the camera to your drone just in case. I tested it with PLA and Advanced PLA, will try wit PETG as well.
Front plate doesn't have holes so put it in place and drill 2mm holes or melt them with soldering iron, allowing for the flex of the material.

title: Big Tugger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Big Tugger is a cable strain relief gadget that has a number of uses but the main ones are by protecting sockets from being accidentally damaged or simply stopping a power cord from being accidentally ripped out when someone trips on a loose cable.

Note: I've improved my design and added it to a new thing here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2452675

This short video explains it all;- https://youtu.be/sWLgZHM7_Ro

Twice now I’ve had my camera monitor fall off the hot shoe adapter. Once was after a bit of camera movement but the second was when I accidentally hooked the HDMI cable and yanked it off. I’m not too concerned about the monitor but both times it ripped out the micro HDMI plug on my Sony with some considerable force. Fortunately the HDMI socket on my camera handled the extreme handling without causing any permanent damage.

I tried Jerkstoppers but they were a pain to use... that's when I decided to build a better cable strain relief and I came up with my design called Tuggers.

The Big Tugger is for protecting sockets by attaching it to cables sized around large mains cables or multiple cables. There are two other sizes that can also be found here:-

Lil' Tugger can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415019

Regular Tugger can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415093

If my video or 3D models didn't answer all your questions then please ask below?

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sWLgZHM7_Ro" ></iframe>

author: ScottyMakesStuff

title: QU-BD OneUp/TwoUp - Extruder and X-Axis Redesign

description.text:
This replaces the X-Axis Belt driven system with a Lead Screw Driven System. All the parts are untested as of this moment. Note that a Hole for the M4x20mm screw will need to be drilled in the Gantry. I will make some detailed instructions when I'm satisfied that this design works. Extra parts to purchase:
(4) M3 x 8mm screws
(2) M3 x 12mm Screws
(2) M3 x 35mm Socket Head Screws (required only for Single Body Extruder)
(8) M3 Hex Nuts
(1) M4 x 20mm Screw
(1) M4 Hex Nut
(1) 5/16-18 x 1" Button Head Screw
(1) 5/16-18 Lock Nut
(1) 7/8" Internal Retaining Clip (OD .943, THK 0.046)
(1) 3/8-12 ACME Lead Screw Nut (from QU-BD Store)
(1) 3/8-12 ACME Lead Screw:
OneUp = Order a Second ACME Lead Screw from the QU-BD Store
TwoUp = will need to order and Cut an ACME Lead Screw to 10 1/2" Long
(1) 3/8-16 Hex Jam Nut (McMaster P/N: 96557A114) for Tensioner Note: Be sure your X-Axis Stepper Motor shaft has not been bent. If it is swap the X-Axis Motor with the Y Axis motor (do not replace it with the Z or the bend will affect your prints). The parts should be updated and work properly. Please let me know of any issues you find in the files.

• Remove the Belt, Stepper Motor, and the Bearing from the X-Axis.
  • Once the above have been removed, remove the Bracket from the back side of the X-gantry (the MDF piece the Stepper Motor was screws into. You will need to remove the Left side Curved support at this point (closest to the Z-Axis)
  • Put the XZSIDEBRACE_-_REPLACEMENT piece in place.
  • remove the Aluminum Pulley from the stepper motor
  • Mount the stepper motor to the X-Axis Motor Relocation Bracket. Be aware the Open Legs are not the end the Stepper motor attaches to. Use 4 M3x8 screws at this point.
  • Attach the stepper motor and bracket to the gantry using the holes the stepper motor was originally mounted to. Be sure the Motor is on the Z-Axis side and that it clears the XZSIDEBRACE Replacement. The original Stepper Motor Screws should be used here with 4 hex nuts.
  • Put the Bearing into the RH_SIDEBRACE (note it may be tight). Use the purchased 7/8" retaining clip at this point to secure the bearing in the bracket.
  • Mount the RH_SIDEBRACE to the X-Gantry. Do Not drill the M4 hole in place at this time. Only use the 5/16 - 1" button head and 5/16" Lock nut to loosely secure it.
  • Build the extruder at this point. The extruder Body and Extruder Bracket go together using the same M3 hardware the original extruder used. The tensioner must be assembled and placed into the extruder at this point as well. The tensioner uses, the same bolt from the original idler/tensioner bearing. The head of the bolt should be towards the bracket with the printed Washer followed by the bearing, then the tensioner, and lastly the hex jam nut. (verify fit before proceeding.
  • Attach the Linear bearings from the original extruder to the nex extruder assembly.
  • Slide the Extruder onto the X-Gantry Rods. you will have to put the bracket through the gantry before the rods go on. Note, this is the most difficult part as the extruder will be heavy and uncooperative.
  • Slide the Threaded rod through the RHSide Bracket, Once through the bracket screw the Lead Screw onto the shaft. Slide the Threaded rod through the extruder Bracket and attach the Lead screw to the Extruder Bracket using 2 M3 x 12 screws and 2 Hex Nuts.
  • Put the Flexible coupler on the stepper motor if you have not already done so.
  • Slide the threaded rod into the Other end of the coupler and Tighten down.
  • Verify the traded rod spins freely in the RH bracket by turning the screw by hand. If it does Drill the M4 Hole at this point. The M4 x 20 screw can now be placed through the two brackets and then both 5/16 and M4 screws can be tightened completely.
  • If the threaded rod is to long, first make a mark about 1 Inch past the RH-Side Bracket. You can then remove it by reversing steps 14 and 12. Cut the threaded rod at the mark, deburr the threaded rod at the cut and replace the threaded rod.
  • Set your EEPROMS settings at this point. The Stepper/mm should match the Z-Axis rod. The Acceleration and Feed may need to be adjusted as the original speed may be too fast for the stepper motor to handle. I was getting decent speed at around 800-1000 before I noticed the bend in my stepper motor shaft.
    • At this point you should be good to go. Any wobble is most likely caused by a bent stepper motor shaft and will be apparent right away. If the motor seems to be hanging or stopping first try tightening the Coupler and verifying its secure. Then try adjusting the stepper motor speed in the EEPROMS. Worst case, a bigger Nema 17 Motor may be needed as the limitations on these Custom Wiring Motors from QU-BD may not be able to handle the change.

comments.text: questions how to get the on up going
Do you have to modify the software at all to get the screw to work?
comments.author: mexkoala

comments.text: You'll have to modify the EEPROMs setting for the x-acid since the default is set to belt steps per mm and the threaded rod will have a different steps per mm
comments.author: mexkoala

comments.text: I see, so over all after using this mod would you say its worth it? I am having issues with my build with the band sticking to the extruder and i haven't been able to print anything because of that. it seems that it just moves a couple of times and then its just the band that moves without the extruder.
comments.author: Jeepguy42

comments.text: Id say its variable. definitely not a definite fix to that problem. I was happy with it when I had it working but I did run the X-Axis a little slower than I would have liked before other issues caused me to change it back. About the same speed as I was getting with the belt. Your issue sounds more like the glue is coming off the belt it self. There are better fixes for that.
comments.author: mexkoala

comments.text:
So now your printer has no belt on the X axis and it has a rod in there instead?
Does it gain anything in precision or... ?
comments.author: BRAINDISIS

comments.text: For the time I had the upgrade installed I actually didn't gain any more precision than with the belt but I lost any change of slipping which at the time I was getting all the time.
comments.author: BRAINDISIS

comments.text: Mhhh but the belt looks dented (from the pictures I see around), how could it slip?
comments.author: Jeepguy42

comments.text: The issue I was having is the glue wasn't adhering properly to the MDF on the extruder assembly. On top of the aluminum Pulley not wanting to tighten down properly so it was constantly slipping.
comments.author: BRAINDISIS

comments.text: Interesting... I can't understand how so many different problems arise on this printer.
comments.author: Jeepguy42

comments.text: Another update for those still watching. The printed parts have shipped. If there are no problems I should receive them Friday and then I can begin assembling. Will post photos as I inspect and build.
comments.author: Jeepguy42

comments.text: Just updating... I've got all the hardware in including the standard Lead Screw Nut from QU-BD plus an Anti Backlash Lead Nut from http://dumpstercnc.comdumpstercnc.com. All I'm waiting for is the 3D parts to be printed and sent to me. Hopefully in the next week they will ship out. I will update with photos when Everything is in as well as when everything is assembled. I will then test a few prints and show results. If all looks good I will switch this from WIP to Released
comments.author: Jeepguy42

comments.text: Okay. The guy got held up a bit but it looks like Friday he'll be shipping the parts to me. Getting closer for me to test finally.
comments.author: Jeepguy42

comments.text: This is kinda cool! What's the advantage of screw over belt? Skipping would be harder, certainly. Can a screw more as fast as a belt, though? I thought that Z was screws because printers move very slowly on Z, but very precisely, and belts on X and Y because they move very rapidly on X and Y...
comments.author: laird

comments.text: The Screw gives you the accuracy and the speed. Most CNC machines can hit the same speed using Screws as belts. Most Machines use the belts as they are normally cheaper in the short run as they will wear out quicker than the screw will.. They use the Screw for Z as its able to lift the gantry/extruder assemblies more efficiently as well as hold the height better than a belt can (belts stretch with Gravity)
comments.author: laird

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2452675

This short video explains it all;- https://youtu.be/sWLgZHM7_Ro

Twice now I’ve had my camera monitor fall off the hot shoe adapter. Once was after a bit of camera movement but the second was when I accidentally hooked the HDMI cable and yanked it off. I’m not too concerned about the monitor but both times it ripped out the micro HDMI plug on my Sony with some considerable force. Fortunately the HDMI socket on my camera handled the extreme handling without causing any permanent damage.

I tried Jerkstoppers but they were a pain to use... that's when I decided to build a better cable strain relief and I came up with my design called Tuggers.

The Regular Tugger is for protecting sockets by attaching it to cables sized around mains cable or up to a couple of HDMI or USB cables. There are two other sizes that can also be found here:-

Lil' Tugger can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415019

Big Tugger can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415089

If my video or 3D models didn't answer all your questions then please ask below?

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sWLgZHM7_Ro" ></iframe>

remixed_from.author: teewuane
remixed_from.title: Toyota Logo Badge for Tacoma Tundra Land Cruiser 4Runner

remixed_from.author: inventimark
remixed_from.title: Classic Parts Contest: Toyota Logo Badge

description.text:
I combined these 2 things and made this combo badge.
It measures 165mm wide X 114mm tall X 15mm deep.
It fits my 2015 Tacoma perfectly.

I paused my print when it was done with the logo, and was just printing the letters, and I pulled out the black filament and jammed in the white filament and resumed the print.

I printed this in ABS, using my standard ABS settings.

I haven't actually mounted this on my truck yet. The white ABS is a UV filament and it changes color when exposed to sunlight. It is supposed to change from white to purple, but it changes from white to pink, so I won't be installing this badge on my truck.
Plus now I think there is too much contrast between the white and black. TOYOTA jumps out at you too much. I'll print it again with the black ABS logo and maybe grey or blue for TOYOTA

One last minor detail: the spot on my grill where this badge mounts to is not flat. I had to heat it up with a plumber's torch and warp it a little bit.

author: taoo2017

description.text:
Simple drill hanger - I have designed it for my cheap, Guild drill.

Contents:
Front holder - 8mm wide, got a 42 mm, half circular gap for front part of drill(chuck) and a little vertical wall to make sure that drill does not move
Rear holder - 8mm wide, got a 50 mm, half circular gap for rear part of drill

Both holders got 4.2mm holes for M4 bolt.

No support required if printed on the side, however, I'd recommend raft.

Make sure you let me know if you like it!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Settings I used:

Layer height: 0.3mm
Infill: 20%
Rafts: 5 line brim

Just drill one hole in a board where you want to hang it then secure a front hanger with M4 bolt. Mark the second hole with a pencil and mark a centre by pressing drill. Turn hanger to move it out of way. When finished secure the second hole with M4 bolt. Try to fit a drill to see where the second hanger should be positioned. Mark the hole to be drilled and repeat the whole process.
Autodesk Fusion 360

author: Terajack

description.text:
I wanted to have a cover for my UM2 extended + to have a closed compartment for ABS printing. I made one from 6mm phenolic or "Pertinax" with white outer color which I got cheap from Ebay (20 Euros for all). It is very sturdy and can be milled easily.
It was milled with a 1.5mm mill.

The connection is like the Ultimaker, with Tabs and screws, I adopted the same method.
This gives a very stable casing which fits very perfect on the UM2.

On the pictures the Polycarbonate windows are missing, I milled these from 8mm PC.

You need a cnc mill to make this.

author: Hughesw1

description.text: It is designed for an iPhone 6s with case. The case adds 1mm to the back and about 1mm to the bottom of the phone.

I bought a 5 gallon bucket of paint at the Habitat for Humanity Restore and it was inexpensive but it needed to be mixed. I needed a paint mixer but I didn't want to pay for one (because obviously I'm cheap). I found a nice one on Thingiverse but it needed supports so I modified it to take off the top ring so that it didn't need supports. You will need a 1/4 inch (7mm) dowel rod also. I used seal-all glue to glue it together.

I have made it but I haven't tried it out yet. As soon as I try it out, I'll update this page.

EDIT:
When I tried to stir the paint with this stirrer, there was apparently too much torque and the dowel rod broke. I redesigned smaller paint stirrers to see if they will have less torque and not break the dowel rod. You can find them in the other objects I have made.

I printed out the IPhone 5, 5c phone stand https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2170064, I had to scale it up by 3200%. This was based on the width of my phone in its case and the dimensions of the phone cord channel. Once scaled up the phone stand was wide enough but the inside dimensions would still not allow my pone to sit in the cradle of the stand even with out the case. to correct this I cut the front sides of the cradle off to allow my phone to fit then created this bracket to slide over the phone stand. The clip inside raises the phone cord up 3mm. this worked fine for one of my cords and the other I had to wrap tape around to get it to fit snugly and raise enough to plug into my phone. I added text to the front of mine but left this one blank for others to edit if they want. This was created in Tinklercad.

description.text:
I was creating a new badge for my Tacoma when it dawned on me that I can customize this some more and replace the Toyota logo with anything. DUH.
Thank you eae01751 for the inspiration!
I'm not from Texas but this jumped into my head so here it is.
comment or message me for more.

comments.text: Pretty cool. There is a slight hollow that is needed on the back in order for it to fit against the existing grill. I did not put it in my original model as I printed it in PLA. I was able to just heat up the print and form the back to the grill.
comments.author: eae01751

comments.text:
I guess I forgot to mention a couple of details.
:)
Yes, the spot on my grill that this mounts to is not flat. I have a plain one on there now.
I heated up the logo with a plumber's torch, slowly, carefully, and formed it to fit.
I also scaled this up to 165mm wide X 114mm tall so it will fit the grill on my 2015 Tacoma.
I made the letters tall enough so when my printer is done printing the logo and it's printing just the letters, I can pause my printer and pull out the black filament, then shove in another color for the letters. Hit resume and we are off to the races!

Tyree is a smiling, tail wagging, sensorless 3d printed robot.  Tyree (he wears a tie and has tires . . .) uses an Arduino motor shield to detect current in the motors. When he strikes an object, it is more difficult to turn the wheel (more current), and that triggers evasive action (so--in a way, there are no external sensors).
Full instructions including software are located at: http://www.instructables.com/id/Tyree-the-Smiling-Tail-Wagging-Sensor-Less-3d-P/ He was printed using a MakerBot Replicator.

title: Coat hanger mount for mountain buggy terrain stroller

description.text:
Taking the laundry home from the dry cleaner while pushing the buggy was quite a hassle. But this is all in the past thanks to the new coat hanger mount!

It is clipped on the handle and locks against the hand brake (therefore only compatible with the mountain buggy terrain or other buggys with hand brakes). You can hang a suit or shirts from the handle bar and it won't touch the ground while you push the buggy.

Have fun!

If you have a different stroller and need another diameter for the handle bar (currently at 30mm), just leave a comment and I will upload the modified version.

author: pedromartinezcampos

description.text: I made this for my friend that had purchased the Relay Shield for the new Spark Core modules. The board fits in the enclosure with access to the screw terminals and also has places for light pipes (I used some PET / TGlass filament but clear PLA should work). There are also two small holes for access to the Spark Core reset and mode buttons. Spark Core info: http://spark.io

Printed in PLA. The lid / top has holes and guide tubes that you can cut off pieces of clear PLA or PET filament (1.75mm) and insert into the tubes. Once the board is installed cut the filament to length so it sits flush with the top then put a dab of glue on the middle part of the filament to hold it in (be careful to not get glue on the ends of the filament "light pipe"). These will serve as light pipes so you can see the relay and core status along with power. You may have to carefully drill the holes out depending on your printer's resolution and detail. Place the board into the top then screw the bottom on using some small self tapping or plastic screws.

description.text:
Wall mounted hinges for baby gate.

If you have a fence system like this https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00020L78M it can be used in single or double sections as door gates. We have 2 sections closing off open pathways we don't want the little one venturing through and have grown tired of having to move it around or step over it all the time.

These hinges allow it to be mounted to the wall and act like a door. I recommend printing 2 sets. One set to mount to the wall and one piece on the other side to act as a door latch to keep it closed.

print_settings.Notes:: Bez podpór/podstaw.

description.text:
Simple mount for KFC32F3 autopilot. Especially for those with limited space in the fuselage. Plate_2 has little tab for easy pulling out.

-insert spring part inside the base part
-glue the base inside fuselage
-screw the autopilot to plate or plate_2 part using M3 screws and spacers
-connect necessary cables
-slide plate inside base

Proste mocowanie dla autopilota KFC32F3. Zaprojektowane z myślą o tych z niewielką ilością miejsca w kadłubie. Płytka 2 jest z niewielkim uchwytem ułatwiającym powtórne wyciąganie.

-wsuń sprężynę (spring) w podstawę (base)
-wklej podstawę w kadłub
-przykęć autopilota do płytki (plate lub plate_2)
-podłącz niezbędne kable
-wsuń płytkę w podstawę

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2360208

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=2360208

Designed to press fit the bearing and the Silver (or Eisenhower) dollars so they can be switched out.

Two Silver dollars fit in each ring. The press fit is fairly tight. Be sure they are centered in the ring for balance.

One can be used in each ring but make sure they are in the same position in the ring and level for balance. You can use a shim (like a quarter) to make sure the dollar is level and at the same height.

If you use three dollars in each ring, they will stick slightly out each side. When you do this, you might want to put a drop of superglue just to make sure things stay in place but it usually isn't necessary.

Using the following options:

weight_type = cylinder
bearing_od = 21.9
weight_od = 37.7
bearing_height = 7
wall_thickness = 5

Every machine is different. These are the customized settings for my machine. I suggest you try this first and tweak from these in customizer in the original model http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2360208

description.text:
!!! [EDIT 05/03/2018] !!! -> https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2815890

Z-Nut for ACME lead screw.
Just buy a 250mm ACME lead screw with 2mm lead (4-5€ from China).
Cut it to 222mm.
Take 4 M3*30 (or M3x40, etc...you can even use bolts, but for me it's enough to screw directly in the plastic).

In your firmware: 3200 steps per unit for a 32 microsteps driver, or 1600 steps per unit for a 16 microsteps driver.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Buddy came to me with his daughter's Ford Escape, and it's broken sun visor. Somehow the mount had broken, the visor was loose, and laying on the floor.

Armed with two beers of overconfidence, I sat down with Fusion 360, and in about 15 minutes had a model. I sent it off to the printer, and an hour later we had a working part in hand.

It installed alarmingly smoothly - and to my buddy's credit - he rewarded us with a case of Mother Road Brewing Tower Station IPA.

I don't know how it could get any better.

title: Dolce Gusto Capsule Rack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This rack is designed for Nescafe Dolce Gusto capsules.

The 9-sided polygonal shape allows storing 9 capsules on the outside and another ca. 7 capsules on the inside, so you can fit an entire small box (16 capsules) in one segment. The segments can be stacked, allowing you to extend your rack as much as you need. At the moment, there are two types of segments: with and without bottom, so that you can combine them to get a higher inside basket.

I will update the rack with a rotative bottom element and a cap soon.

Makers, please share your prints and nice colour combinations!

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

The print will take about 54g in full scale and ca 4 hours at 60 mm/s
After the print is done, you might need to sand off the edges of the holes , to get a better fit of the capsules. It really depends on your printer and how much overextrusion it has.

description.text:
Pocketlab is a small device that has a number of built in sensors for gathering and visualizing information through a freely available app.

Pocketlab is a great tool in a math or science classroom. It can be used to demonstrate various forces with the ability to gather and analyze data.

This is a simple enclosure for the Pocketlab which let's you use the Pocketlab similar to a fidget spinner.

The centripetal force is useful for demonstrating concepts like the g-force that roller coasters or rockets experience during travel.

description.text:
I'm a big Sf fan, so I will try to convert as much Sketchup Sfi Fi models as I can !  This is the first, an old favorite of me.  
Added a second file with the parts cut up to produce a printable version.   
Also added the original Sketchup files (*.SKP) so people can adjust the parts themselves.

If needed devide it in seperate files using Sketchup.. Better to print the space frame, and body front- and end section (with supporting space frame) separate at a slow speed.
Joined all parts afterwards using Bison Kit super glue gel. It is an accurate scale model so take care that the small parts wil disappear when printed to small (I had to check the slices view in Cura for my Ultimaker very often to make sure I was not printed in mid air...) Had some trouble making the engine part because of the delicate construction and the small scale I printed.
I replaced these parts using paperclips...

description.text:
Cellphone and Laptop Patio Charging Station.

Tired of tripping over power cords? How many times have your legs grabbed the charging cables which brought your devices to the ground?

You can easily pop the charging station on and off. Made to fit standard size patio umbrella poles. Just attach a long extension cord which serves as your power source.

Use a zip tie to secure the extension cord to the holder. You can print multiple cord holders if you would like the extension cord neatly attached below the table.

Please be sure to unplug the power when not in use. This charging station is not water safe from rain or sprinklers. Use at your own risk.

title: TronXY P802MA Warped Carriage Levelling Washers M3

description.text:
You can fix warped x axis carriages for the lead screw attachment by printing 3mm washers with outside diameter of 4mm, inside 3mm and 0.2mm high.

I printed like 100 for less than a metre of PLA. Took a whole minute to print lol. Then I just packed the washers between the screws holding the lead screw guide/nut to the carriages.

You know when you have it right when the rod falls through the nut under gravity or a very small tap and if it is parallel to the guide rail. This adjustment process took about an hour because of the fiddly nature of it. But it worked like a champ. A razor blade and toothpick helps to align them.

Less material than printing a new carriage and faster. I plan to epoxy this in place because that nut should be a permanent part of the carriage.

It's customisable, the code is included as an scad file.

description.text:
A dock for the oneplus 5 phone.

It has a small sound amplifier (sufficient for me needs).
It's designed for :

  • The official USB 3 cable dimensions so that it fit (the one delivered with the phone).
  • Phone + official case size (should be fine without the case, less tight in this case).

Glue is not mandatory for the cable but can help to ensure it does not go away when you take the phone.
Another solution, is to add few adhesive tape rounds on the head of the USB cable so that it fit tightly the hole (that's what I did).

The blender file is attached so that you can easily remix it (it's made of boolean operations and holes are on layer #3)

In files you'll also find a version with less tight stand (78.2mm x 8.9mm) if you have a bigger case than mine.

description.text:
Your looking at a Slim case for the PanelDue 4.3". It's a total of 16mm thick.

The matching case for the rear PCB is also 16mm thick only.
Meant to be mounted under the printer.

The rear ø3,4mm holes in both cases are meant for various mount options, where I've made one for PCB-box so far.

There are optional buttons for Erase and Reset for the PCB-Case

BOM LCD

  • 4x m3 nuts - LCD
  • 4x m3 16mm screws - LCD
  • 2x m3 xx mm screws - LCD bracket
  • xx To mount bracket to printer

BOM PCB box

  • 3x m3 nuts - PCB
  • 3x m3 15 screws - PCB
  • 2x m3 nuts - Bracket PCB
  • 2x m6 screws - Bracket PCB

BOM misc

  • 2x screws to attach bracket to printer
  • 40-pin IDC/GPIO Male to Female cable
  • You can use the DuPont connectors/cables

I'm going to be using it for my BeTrue3D Printer project (opens my blog).

Printer:

My Crossbot design

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes:
  • Used 0.4mm nozzle
  • I printed mine using .02mm layers
  • 2 borders/perimeters
  • 25% infill
  • Printed in black PETG

Insert m3 nuts Screw on your mountbracket of choice Mounting option in place. Place the PCB and make sure it fits snugly. Make ready for the PressureButtons if you want to use these. Place the PressureButtons inside the pcb top - Or leave them out. Make sure to test the Erase and Reset buttons. - or leave them out entirely.

Naming convention

Naming 4.3-4.3 is because there's a bit of confusion, but the LCD itself is 4.2 while the display is 4.3" if that makes sense. Important thing is that they are the same regardless of wheter listed as 4.2 or 4.3.

Prepare LCD bracket of choice. Install bracket using a pair of m3 6mm screws or longer.

Feel free to follow my work

If you like what I do, you should go take a look at my Blog on 3D stuff.

I'm going to be using this particular design for my BeTrue3D Printer project (opens my blog).
You need 8 10mm diameter X 3mm hight magnets

These where made using a a single exturder and swapping the filament at different layer heights.

First layer prints 2 mm high for a solid base. Then .5 mm high for the following colors. The models are designed to print in a certain order.

Hearts: 2 mm White; .5 mm Black, .5 mm Red
Rupee: 2 mm Black; .5 mm White; .5 mm Green
Ocarina: 2 mm Black; .5 mm Blue; .5 mm White

Heart

title: R/C Spare tyres / wheels for DF Mali Storm Fighter 2

description.text:
My son has a DF Mali Storm Fighter 2 RC race car. It causes a lot of wear to the wheels and spare parts are rather expensive. My intention was to design a very cost effective solution!
So here you have a model for the front and rear wheel. Additionally, you need:

  • rubber O-rings 75x5x65mm (3 for each rear wheel, 2 for the front wheel)
    For the front wheel:
  • ball bearings of the type 625ZZ 16 x 5 x 5mm (2 per wheel)
    The holes for the axes need to be drilled to size, they are smaller by intention.
    The seats for the bearings are press fits. Please press in by applying pressure to the outer bearing ring to avoind damaging of the bearing. (Use a wrench socket, for example.)

Off-road, wheels can be used without o-rings.

Have fun!

print_settings.Notes:: Honeycomb infill.  6mm brim.  6 loop skirt. 212 degree extruder and 75 degree bed. PLA material.

description.text:
I printed some modular vertical frame braces to reduce wobble in the z-x plane to less than 0.1mm relative movement at the top of the z axis. Note this was crudely measured.

At this stability it is an angular error of 0.026 degrees and the deviation in mm in the plane vertical alignment is equal to:
the z axis printing height x 0.000454.

The multiplier comes from the tangent of the angular error.

The braces fit together with dowels that are friction fit. They fit between the horizontal surfaces of the acrylic frame.

There is some movement along the rod, you can try different infill patterns or increase the diameter to get more rigidty but make sure they don't get in the way of the carriages or anything else.

Scad files included for customisation.

You need two frame braces and two dowels and one rod for each side. It might be easier to print two sets of the above all together so you have a complete brace for each side.

If you need to make slight adjustments, you can print a washer to put between the brace sections and the rod. If the dowels are tight don't force them, lightly sand them. A friction fit doesn't matter much here as the part is in compression. Don't bend the rods sideways or they will break!.

You might experiment with a different cross section to get more rigid rods. This is left as an exercise for the reader LOL.

Actually the braces can be printed alone and the rod replaced with copper pipe or tubing 15mm outside diameter (OD). The base of the brace is 16mm OD and the shaft is 12mm OD. Copper pipe is very strong and rigid and cheap. Again fine adjustments can be made with a 0.2mm high printed washer at the base of the pipe. You might have a piece laying around.

Printer:

TronXY P802MA

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Honeycomb infill. 6mm brim. 6 loop skirt. 212 degree extruder and 75 degree bed. PLA material.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lWbmX6Xy597

title: Laser collimator with adjustment for 6mm laser modules

description.text:
This thing is inspired by this one:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2372177
Unfortunately, the (china) laser modules that I have are all quite off axis, so I decided I need a version where you can compensate for this.
The laser module bore in this variant is a step bore that features 2 mm diameter for the laser beam to pass the adjustment plane, a 6 mm part to center the front of the laser module, and a wider part which provides room for adjustment. Adjustment is done by means of 3 M3 screws. The bores are 2.6mm diameter, so that a M3 thread can be cut in.

Adjustment procedure is simply done by turning the thing with laser on while sitting in the ocular mount and adjust the 3 screws until the spot does no longer move when the collimator is turned.

Procedure to adjust the telescope is to first center the laser spot on the main mirror then align reflected spot to center on collimator display. Plenty stuff is online on this.

And, of course, DO NOT STARE INTO THE LASER BEAM!!!

Part list:

  • 6mm laser module (just google for "6mm laser module")
  • some power supply for it (battery),
  • M3 thread cutter
  • 3 M3 screws, about 20 mm long

Printer:

anet a8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

50% zigzag

Notes:

I used gray PLA @ 205° on a glass bed @ 60°.
It worked OK for me without any support, printed as in the file. Photo is upside down. The overhang looks a bit ugly but this does not impact functionality. I preferred to have the diagonal adjustment plane and the limiter ring face in good quality.
Ocular diameter is 31.84mm, which is a bit more than nominal but fits my telescope very well. You may want to scale the whole thing by some sub-percent to make it fit.

description.text:
I was fed up with having to scrape my fingers around in the little storage niches to pick up coins for tolls or parking so I came up with this nifty little coin storage bin to fit in the centre console drinks holder which you can just pick up and empty into your hand.
It's designed specifically for a UK spec Ford Focus Mk3 but should work for some other UK / European cars - dimensions on next page. From what I've seen, US drinks holders tend to be somewhat larger.

Print this upside-down from CoinBin-Print.stl. The photo shows mine printed at 0.2mm, 3 shells and 20% fill, raftless without support. I've domed the internal surface to help printing but there's still a bit of a gap to bridge at the very top and the inside of mine is slightly rough here. However, this is a design which fitted perfectly on the first try so I'm pretty chuffed. The coins pack down pretty well because of the taper and don't rattle as I thought they might. I've used it a few times now and found it so much easier than scrabbling around for coins. I may add a lid at some point so the loose change isn't visible when the car is parked. The widest part of this is 73mm, tapering down to 63mm at the base. Height is 55mm and the clip to the cup gap is 12mm.
With a small mod, (extend the clip gap by 5mm or so) this would be a good fit for a Mk2 Focus so I'll add that if anyone's interested.

title: Prusa PCB Factory : Draw and Drill pcbs

description.text:
How to use your 3D printer to help mking PCBs ?
This is an experiment to show how a 3D printer can be used for drawing and drilling PCBs.

I have designed a tool holder to allow adding Tools to the printer head.
The principle is that the Tools does not replace or impact the 3D printing feature.
Add the tool when you need it, remove it when you want to 3D print....

A small utility software is needed to convert circuit designs into gcode files : I use Design Spark 7.2 to design the pcb, then a utility script that converts files into gcode information. Objective is to be able to draw with a etch resist pen and drill on pcb copper clads. ( etching is still needed).

The key principle is that the utility software will read the pcb design and generate a gcode file to print a plastic support on your printer bed at a precise position and that will have the exact dimensions of the PCB you want to build. ( generated gcode files uses 1,75mm PLA filament, a ini file needs to be modified to use different printer settings).

You need to leave the plastic support sticked in place, and even reinforce it in this position by using some additional scotch so that it doesnt move from it's position. Now that the support is printed, you can put the copper clad on it and launch gcode files to draw and drill at precise positions.

Following are 4 points to be able to reproduce this experiment :

A. FIND A WAY TO FIX THE TOOL HOLDER on the printer without removing the PLA head.
I provide some stl files to hold the pen and drill, but you can use any other solution to hold the pen and drill tool . Please just pay attention to a few things :
1) The printer will home before it draws. the gohome (x=0,y=0,z=0) must be working fine with the tools mounted. on my printer when in go to home position, the pen or drill tool is outside the bed. which is what we want.
2) The tool holder should not replace the printer PLA head. The idea is to add a tool holder to your printer without impacting the 3D printing capabilities .
3) I have done my tests only on a prusa emotion tech printer. some design activities may be needed for any other printer.
4) The Tool holder are modular ;you will typically need to screw together a tool slider and a tool holder of the correct diameter . This should then slide into the MultitoolRail. sand a bit if it does not slide easy enough,

B CALIBRATE the Tools :
The procedure to caligrate each tool ( pen or drill ) is easy : the plastic support has an arrow : move manually the edge of the pen or drill tool to the edge of the Arrow position. then read x,y,z values from your printer.
You can then update the ini file with this information and generate all the gcode files to draw and drill.. the gcode files will know exactly how to move the Tools on the plastic support....
Note : you can also edit easily the generated gcode file with the x,y,z information that you read, i will post an example in a different thingiverse post.

C PRINT and DRILL the PCB
When you have prepared the calibration and generated the gcode files, then you can put your copper clad on the plastic support on your printer bed. This means that your copper clad will be at a precisely known position on your printerbed .

You can run the pen_copper_top.gcode to draw the pcb.... the pen will move on the coper clad and draw the pcb tracks.
You need to etch the pcb.
Then you can launch the gcode to drill ( there is one gcode file per drill size) .

D SOFTWARE :
The utiliy software will require the following additional free software :

  • slic3r.exe must be installed on the computer
  • openscad.exe must be installed on the computer
  • DesignSpark 7.2 PCB editing sofware is needed to export odb++ files.

More detailed instructions, and download ( non free) of the utility :
http://prusapcbfactory.highlevelbits.fr/index.php

You can also test the concept with a test circuit board : it is a circuit board to host a MCP3008 volt Analog converter (SPI).

print_settings.Notes:: 5 outer lines for strength.

description.text:
I used these with a 4' piece of 2x2x1/4" steel angle iron to straighten the cheap Chinese linear rails that I bought for my Hypercube Evolution. Jig everything up as shown in the picture with a dial indicator and gently pry the rods to straighten them. It will take about 30 minutes per rod so have some patience.

Bearings will be a tight press fit. Use a couple wood blocks and a vice to install.
608z for 8mm
6200zz for 10mm
6001z for 12mm

I was able to get my rods to .001" with these by SLOWLY working them. Use a small prybar or large flat blade screwdriver wrapped with masking tape to protect the shaft.

The 8mm version should also work for lead screws but is still untested. Let me know if it works.

Also, make sure your printer prints accurate to scale. If not you may need to adjust scaling in your slicer.

No

5 outer lines for strength.

comments.text:

title: Reinforcement Plate for Polar Pro LED for 3DR Solo

description.text:
The Polar Pro LED light bars for the 3DR Solo are cool, but fragile.

The first time attempting to put the Solo into its backpack, the bottom plastic trim edge below the LEDs broke off because it caught against the foam. I've since used a knife to cut away some of the foam in the backpack to make room for the LED bar. The plastic edge broke off because it isn't supported, and is only attached at the ends. I suspect that this slot is used to slide the self adhesive LED strip into the plastic mount. This brace covers up that slot, and secures that thin strip of plastic against abuse.

I used Moment of Inspiration to design simple plastic planks that you can glue to the Polar Pro LED light bars using RC airplane Canopy glue. This glue dries clear, and can be peeled off if you really want to disassemble it. Your local hobby shop should carry this glue. Looks like Elmer's Glue until it cures.

title: Filament Guide for German RepRap X400

description.text:
Update July 30th 2017:
Uploaded improved version "MK2" for much better attachment to the printer's metal block.

This simple filament guide prevents the filament fed into the left extruder from scrubbing against the cables and electrical connectors of the extruder unit. Just click this thing on the extruder's bearing block (X-axis) and feed filament through its eye.

Update 30.07.2017:
Verbesserte Version "MK2" mit deutlich verbessertem Halt am Metallblock des Druckers.

Diese einfache Filamentfuehrung verhindert, dass das Filament fuer den linken Extruder an dessen Kablen und Steckern scheuert. Das Teil wird einfach auf den Lagerbock der X-Achse gesteckt. Das Filament wird anschliessend durch die Oese gefuehrt.

Printer:

German RepRap X400 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

15

Notes:

Brim: 6 turns, 1 Layer
Thin wall behavior: No infill

Although I printed the thing in PLA, I recommend to print it in ABS! As this guide is installed inside the X400 printer it must withstand very high ambient temperatures. When the X400 is operated in ABS mode its build-plate is heated up to 100°C the PLA material of the guide will get weak and thus will be deformed.

Obwohl ich das Teil mit PLA gedruckt habe, empfehle ich den Ausdruck in ABS! Da die Filamentfuehrung im Innenraum des X400 installiert wird, kann sich das PLA beim Betrieb des Druckers im ABS-Modus durch die hohe Innenraumtemperatur (100°C Build-plate) verformen.

title: Sliding Patio Door Security Bar Retainer Bracket

description.text:
This is a replacement for the retaining bracket that locks in place the security bar (a.k.a. "burglar bar"), which prevents the sliding patio door from being forced open. The plastic "ears" on the original retainers to all three of our patio doors had broken off after 8 years of use.

I thought this would be the perfect project to demonstrate the "value" of my new 3D printer to my better-half. My CAD experience dates back to prehistoric times (circa 1980's), so it took me about 3 days to learn enough about using OnShape (OnShape.com) cloud based CAD system to design the retainer bracket and print out three of them.

It is a hard business case to make for making the three brackets: $400 for the printer, $20 for filament and three days of my time, but the feeling of creativity and accomplishment is priceless. Well at least that's my story and I'm sticking to it.

description.text:
Replacement part for 1998 Honda Civic hood latch. The pull part on the Civic hood latch can snap off in cold temperatures, and the only replacement available is the entire latch and cable.

This design allows you to superglue this replacement latch over the remaining plastic on the cable from your last latch. It's customizable, so if you opt to remove the old plastic, you could decrease the inner cylinder size.

I used superglue to attach this latch. I sanded down the old plastic, and filed the inside of the new latch slightly for a perfect fit. The photo is of the latch in place on the car.

comments.author: 8ung

description.text:
Un petit réducteur pour votre extruder, histoire de faire passer les fils qui d’habitude vous agace car il n’arrête pas de claquer ou si vous voulez réduire le diamètre de votre buse.

Cela fait 2 mois que je l’ai mis en service et je n’ai plus de problème. Pas d’usure apparente malgré une dizaine de kilo de PLA passé.

Il faudra récupérer le bras d’extruder d’origine de la discoeasy ainsi que le guide fil, le ressort et l’engrenage d’entrainement du fil pour le montage (sans oublier le nema 17…) et ajouter:

  • une vis de diamètre 5mm
  • 3 roulements 685zz
  • une rondelle 5mm
  • quelques écrous de diam 5mm
  • et 4 vis tête fraisé bois de diamètre 3.5mm.

Le montage est simple :

  • Fixer le Nema sur le support en intégrant le pied de l’ensemble
  • Passer la vis de 5mm dans 2 685zz puis dans le support de l’extruder
  • Placer deux écrous pour maintenir la tête de vis contre les roulements et serrer
  • Placer la roue de 60 dents dans le dernier écrou que vous venez de serrer et bloquer avec un écrou (encore…)
    Là, il va falloir s’armé de patience et faire preuve d’adresse….
  • Enfiler le capot
    A partir de là, tout passe par la fente du bras d’extruder
  • Enfiler le dernier roulement et le loger dans son emplacement sur le capot
  • Placer une rondelle diam 5mm
  • Enfiler l’engrenage d’extrusion (la roue en cuivre…. Pardonner mon manque de vocabulaire technique !). j’ai mis un coup de taraud dans le mien, histoire de ne pas avoir à forcer pendant le montage.
  • Enfiler un écrou (pour ce dernier, j’ai mis un nylstop)
  • Visser le capot
  • Et serrer le tout (sans oublier l’ecrou du dernier roulement)
  • Remonter le bras avec le ressort de votre extruder
    Normalement, sur la table il vous reste 2 vis de 3mm de votre ancien extruder. Je vous expliquerai comment les utiliser dans un prochain projet fini mais encore en test : une imprimante core XY grand format beaucoup plus abouti que l’ensemble que vous venez de monter.

Ce n’est pas fini…

Il faut maintenant paramétrer votre firmware (chez moi, Marlin RC8) en modifiant le pas moteur de l’extruder.

  • Il faud d’abord inverser le sens de rotation du nema (et oui, on a mis un engrenage !) Pour ce faire, rechercher la ligne dans configuration.h :
    « #define INVERT_E0_DIR false »
    Et remplacer « false » par « true »

  • Rechercher la ligne suivante dans configuration.h :
    « #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT { 80, 80, 1600, 98 }”
    Chez moi le 1600 est mis car j’ai des vis trapez pas de 2 sur Z donc il est possible que chez vous, vous ayez une valeur proche des 2500 si vous êtes en config d’origine avec les vis en pas de 1.25.
  • Il faut modifier la valeur (98) par 285 qui correspond à la valeur du pas moteur. Cette valeur pourra être ajustée dans votre calibrage. La méthode est simple :
    o Enlever la gaine bowden de votre extruder
    o Couper le fil au raz de la sortie d’extruder
    o Extruder grâce à votre imprimant 100mm de fil
    o Mesurer le fil sorti de l’extruder avec un pied à coulisse
    o Ajuster la valeur dans votre firmware avec une règle de 3
    o Recommencer l’opération jusqu’à satisfaction

Et voilà qui est fait !

A l’usage, il faudra élargir le pied car le poids du Nema peut faire basculer l’ensemble (sans gravité), non fait car le l’ai fixer sur le cadre de mon nouveau projet.

Il faudrait prévoir une roue de 60 dents ajourée pour faciliter le serrage du Nema. Je test actuellement des roue a chevrons dans une réduction différente mais qui se monte parfaitement sur l’ensemble qui règle ce problème. Je les glisserai en mise à jour dès que cela sera concluant.

Toujours à l’écoute des remarques pour faire avancer le schmilblick donc n’hésitez pas....

Bonnes impressions a tous....
Laptop basket. Please contact me for personalization.
Does your garden hose valve match the image? Maybe this is a workable valve handle for you, My print just clips on.

author: caracarn

description.text:
This is a welded follow rest to fit a Hardinge TL-10 lathe. Feel free to adjust it to fit other lathes! It is designed to be cut from 1/4" plate using plasma cutting, though waterjet and laser would work fine too. CNC would also work.

The key to success on this is to pay attention to the cut-off tabs and leave them in place till you finish welding. Start by cleaning all the slag off your parts and grinding to bare metal any place you will be welding. Stack up the front and back plates and line them up carefully. Clamp them at least 4 places and then tack at least 6 places. DO NOT weld in the finger slots! Weld up all the edges EXCEPT where the brace fits in the corner. If you are going to mill the slots, go ahead and do it now. You can remove the tabs now if you want to. On mine, I used 1" x 3/8" cold rolled steel for the fingers, though the plasma cut fingers would have worked fine. Please be aware if you cut the finger slots a little deeper than 1/4", you will later have to mill the end of the back finger a bit thinner; otherwise it will catch on the two front fingers.
After doing any finish work on the slots, weld the foot and brace in place, and smooth all corners. Try to get the foot square to the front/back assembly.
You need the foot to be flat. After welding and grinding, you can either create a flat surface on it by putting epoxy on the foot and setting it on a flat surface that has been treated with mold release, or mill it flat. I milled it, then had some fun scraping it even flatter.
The three bolts to hold the fingers are 3/8"-16. The holes are undersize so that you can drill them to size and ensure they are round.

In use, move the follow rest as close to the headstock as possible, and slide each finger firmly against the work piece, and clamp them in place. Lube the work/fingers regularly.

I don't recommend using rollers on these; they will tend to suck chips in and either ding or bump the work. Tried it...
